occurrences.line_text: At length it chaunst, that both their hands on hie,
By which he had to her both life and loue restord.
Was like enchantment, that through both the eares,
And both the eyes did steale the hart away.
Against both which that knight wrought knightlesse shame.
He her not finding, both them thus nigh dead did leaue.
Both for that newes he did to her impart,
Both to her loue; and to her selfe in that sad dreare.
And twixt them both with parted paines did beare,
So hauing both found fit occasion,
To make them both as merry as he may.
So both conspiring, gan to intimate
Of which whilest they discoursed both together,
Hauing both sides through grypt with griesly wound.
But both his challenge and him selfe contemned,
And that this Lady, both whose sides are pearst
But both himselfe reuil'd, and eke his loue;
Both speare and shield, as things that needlesse were,
Both for the perill of the present stound,
In seeking all the woods both farre and nye
Agreeing well both with the place and season,
Both horse and armes, and what so else to lend,
Mongst saluage beasts, both rudely borne and bred,
Now wringing both his wretched hands in one,
And faithfully did serue both day and night,
So now they be arriued both in sight
Who both in minde, the which most grieueth me,
Was forced there to leaue them both behynd,
The Hermite heales both Squire and dame
Gainst all, both good and bad, both most and least,
Gainst all, both good and bad, both most and least,
Of that good Hermite both they tooke their leaue,
And went both on their way, ne ech would other leaue.
So both together traueld, till they met
That both thy loue, for lacke of hardiment,
The which were armed both agreeably,
And both combynd, what euer chaunce were blowne,
They should accomplish both a knightly deed,
With that they both at once with equall spight
Did bend their speares, and both with equall might
How both he and his fellow there in place
He bad his eyes to be vnblindfold both,
For both so wilfull were and obstinate,
Led in a rope, which both his hands did bynd;
I will them soone acquite, and both of blame assoile.
Yet seem'd the soyle both fayre and frutefull eft,
And caroling her name both day and night,
Both of his speach that wrought him great content,
But in that litle is both rich and wise.
And this your cabin both my bowre and hall.
Three other Ladies did both daunce and sing,
Both of his words, which he with reason red;
Both his estate, and loue from skill of any wight.
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
Both clad in shepheards weeds agreeably,
And both with shepheards hookes: But Calidore
To whom they both agreed to take their way,
Whereof they both full glad and blyth did rest,
Both whom they goodly well did entertaine;
This bottle thus before you with such toile,
Here in this bottle (sayd the sory Mayd)
Yet is the bottle leake, and bag so torne,
That through the waues one might the bottom see,
Shee sight from bottome of her wounded brest,
Ne ought mote euer sinke downe to the bottome there.
Lay hidden in the bottome of the pot;
Deepe in the bottome of the sea, her bowre
His bowre is in the bottome of the maine,
Downe in the bottome of the deepe Abysse,
And thousand vowes from bottome of his hart
Deepe in the bottome of an huge great rocke
The waters depth, and doth their bottome tread;
Blowne downe, it shakes the bottome of the bulke,
That foot of man might sound the bottome plaine,
Boue all the sonnes, that were of earthly wombes ybore.
Boue all her sexe that euer yet was seene;
But Satyrane boue all the other crew,
With that out of his bouget forth he drew
He pluckt a bough; out of whose rift there came
The bleeding bough did thrust into the ground,
And she more sweet, then any bird on bough,
She hauing hong vpon a bough on high
To win a willow bough, whilest other weares the bayes.
Of flyes vpon a birchen bough doth cluster,
And with greene boughes decking a gloomy glade,
And at his feet their laurell boughes did throw.
With boughes and arbours wouen cunningly,
Couer'd with boughes & shrubs from heauens light,
With boughes and braunches, which did broad dilate
For both the boughes doe laughing blossomes beare,
Whose shadie boughes sharpe steele did neuer lop,
And with their boughes the gentle plants did beat.
Where he with boughes hath built his shady stand,
Deckt with greene boughes, and flowers gay beseene.
O too deare loue, loue bought with death too deare.
Sowen in bloudy field, and bought with woe:
Bought with the bloud of vanquisht Paynim bold:
And Ladies loue to leaue so dearely bought?
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
I cast to pay, that I so dearely bought;
The guilt I doe ascribe: deare wisedome bought too late.
Life is not lost, (said she) for which is bought
Whence dearely she with death bought her desire.
For from the time that Scudamour her bought
That she might win some time, though dearly bought
Where is the bootie, which therefore I bought,
The fruite of ioy and blisse, though long time dearely bought.
Yet was in knots and many boughtes vpwound,
Whose wreathed boughts when euer he vnfoldes,
Saying, he now had boulted all the floure,
They snuf, they snort, they bou[n]ce, they rage, they rore,
A bounch of haires discolourd diuersly:
And on his arme a bounch of keyes he bore,
Emongst that bounch, to open it withall;
Whose bounches hanging downe, seemed to entice
Knotted with bloud, in bounches rudely ran,
Now a loose Leman to vile seruice bound:
I deeme your loue, and hold me to you bound;
Yet liue perforce in balefull darkenesse bound?
And boasts, in beauties chaine not to be bound,
And taught the way that does to heauen bound?
Attacht that faitor false, and bound him strait:
And bound him hand and foote with yron chains.
As bound by them to liue in liues despight,
And whither now on new aduenture bound.
And many-folded shield he bound about his wrest.
And both her hands fast bound vnto a stake,
And both his hands fast bound behind his backe,
Hath now fast bound, me met in middle space,
Art thou now bound? for well mote I discerne
Then loe, where bound she sits, who[m]; thou hast sought,
His owne woes authour, who so bound it findes,
Did lightly leape, where he them bound did see,
Did stretch themselues without the vtmost bound
But to be euer bound
Are not all knights by oath bound, to withstond
Which from Alcluid to Panwelt did that border bound.
To draw their boate within the vtmost bound
They tooke them both, & both them strongly bound
And round about the pots mouth, bound the thread,
Them bound till his returne, their labour not to slake.
With which the stubborn feends he to his seruice bound.
From thence, him firmely bound with faithfull band,
She with him bound, and Congï¿½ tooke withall.
Are bound with commun bond of frailtee,
We both are bound to follow heauens beheasts,
And with it bound the beast, that lowd did rore
Which with a teeme of scaly Phocas bound
And Ouert gate by North: that is the bound
Toward the land; two riuers bound the rest.
Are bound for to reuenge, and punish if they may.
Had not the Lady, which by him stood bound,
He bound that pitteous Lady prisoner, now relest,
Himselfe she bound, more worthy to be so,
Which doft, her golden lockes, that were vp bound
And by the tailes together firmely bound,
And mighty spirites bound with mightier band,
Sir Artegall, who all this while was bound
And of the perils whereto he was bound,
Of Kings and Keasars, to thy seruice bound,
And bad them, if so be they were not bound,
And with a litle golden chaine about it bound.
Vpon his vsuall beast it firmely bound,
And bound them with inuiolable bands;
The dongeon was, in which her bound he left,
Bound like a beast appointed to the stall:
That euery one doe know their certaine bound,
Ne loose that he hath bound with stedfast band.
Fast bound on euery side with iron bands,
My law, and euer to my lore be bound;
There bound t'obay that Amazons proud law,
Yet so, as bound to me he may continue still.
Bound vnto me, but not with such hard bands
I to your selfe should rest for euer bound,
She quickly caught her sword, & shield about her bound.
To serue her so, as she the rest had bound.
With a strong yron chaine and coller bound,
Gaue leaue vnto his ghost from thraldome bound,
They all were bound to all posterities to raise.
But by that Tyrant is in wretched thraldome bound.
Which may a Knight assure, had surely bound,
Both hand and foote vnto a tree was bound:
Her selfe acknowledg'd bound for that accord,
And her selfe bound to him for euermore;
But I am bound by vow, which I profest
From him, to whom she was for euer bound:
She was borne free, not bound to any wight,
Were bound about, and voyded from before,
And bound him fast: Tho when he vp did looke,
Him to haue bound, and thrald without delay;
Who all this while stood there beside them bound,
So leaue we her in wretched thraldome bound,
This daughter thought in wedlocke to haue bound
Against his will fast bound in yron chaine,
I bounden am streight after this emprize,
Fast bounden hand and foote with cords of wire,
Were bounden fast, that did her ill become,
And often bounding on the brused gras,
Nor bounds nor banks his headlong ruine may sustaine.
And looser thoughts to lawfull bounds withdraw;
Did beat and bounse his head and brest full sore;
Yet still he bet, and bounst vppon the dore,
Ne wanted ought, to shew her bounteous or wise.
But to the mighty victour yields a bounteous feast.
Did breath out bounteous smels, & painted colors shew.
Loe loe how braue she decks her bounteous boure,
Vnto thy bounteous baytes, and pleasing charmes,
An armed knight, of bold and bounteous grace,
And to her guestes doth bounteous banket dight,
Thereto so bounteous and so debonaire,
For loue does alwayes bring forth bounteous deeds,
Should euer enter in his bounteous thought,
In gentle Ladies brest, and bounteous race
Sith that more bounteous creature neuer far'd
Dwels in thy bounteous brest? what couldst thou more,
And bounteous Trent, that in him selfe enseames
And thus bespake; Sir knight, your bounteous proffe[r]
Of wondrous beauty, and of bountie rare,
One that to bountie neuer cast his mind,
Her iuorie forhead, full of bountie braue,
The gifts of soueraigne bountie did embrace:
That is her bountie, and imperiall powre,
Her bountie she abated, and his cheare empayrd.
And his large bountie rightly doth areed.
Of bountie, and of beautie, and all vertues rare.
In whose chast breast all bountie naturall,
And with her beautie bountie did compare,
Dew'd with her drops of bountie Soueraine,
The bountiest virgin, and most debonaire,
Conceiue such soueraine glory, and great bountihed?
On firme foundation of true bountihed;
She seemd a woman of great bountihed,
In all chast vertue, and true bounti-hed
Whose bounty more then might, yet both he wondered.
But full of Princely bounty and great mind,
Which with her bounty and glad countenance
Ne blot the bounty of all womankind;
Her soueraigne bounty, and celestiall hew,
Whose beauty doth her bounty far surpasse,
Of all the bounty, which Belphebe threw
For her great bounty knowen ouer all,
From heauenly seedes of bounty soueraine,
Emongst his young ones shall diuide with bountyhed.
Loe loe how braue she decks her bounteous boure,
There he did find in her delitious boure
His Leman from the Stygian Princes boure.
My litle boat can safely passe this perilous bourne.
Deepe busied bout worke of wondrous end,
Whilest thus they busied were bout Florimell,
Bout which whilest he was busied thus hard,
And in his hand did beare a bouzing can,
Lay now thy deadly Heben bow apart,
But misseth bow, and shaftes, and buskins to her knee.
Ah Loue, lay downe thy bow, the whiles I may respire.
So farre as Ewghen bow a shaft may send,
As she the woods with bow and shafts did raunge,
And at her backe a bow and quiuer gay,
Wandreth alone with bow and arrowes keene,
When hauing laid his cruell bow away,
His cruell bow, wherewith he thousands hath dismayd.
And euery one did bow and arrowes beare:
And in his hand a bended bow was seene,
And his mischieuous bow full readie bent,
Discharged of his bow and deadly quar'le,
Did bow adowne, as ouer-burdened.
Drew out a deadly bow and arrow keene,
His bootelesse bow in feeble hand vpcaught,
Her bow and gilden quiuer lying him beside.
Her bow and painted quiuer, had vnlaste
When her discolourd bow she spreds through heauens hight.
A mortall bow and arrowes keene did hold,
Did to that image bow their humble knee,
Like shaft out of a bow preuenting speed.
That with the force it backward forced him to bow.
With bow in hand, and arrowes ready bent,
And euer in her bow she ready shewed
So sore, that to his saddle bow thereby
On which when Cupid with his killing bow
Her goodly bow, which paints the liquid ayre;
That seem'd a marble pillour it could bow:
And eke the Bull hath with his bow-bent horne
And bowd his battred visour to his brest:
And falling lowly at his feet, her bowd
That to the ground him meekely made to bowe,
And bowed low, that her right well became,
Meekely she bowed downe, to weete if life
He bowed low, and so a while did lie:
With bowed backe, by reason of the lode,
Out of his mothers bowelles, and it made
And bowels gushing forth: well worthy end
Amid the bowels of the earth full steepe,
Ne can be quencht, within my secret bowels bee.
The bowels of wide Fraunce, a forlorne Dame,
Within my bleeding bowels, and so sore
Which in these troubled bowels raignes, & rageth rife.
Closely the wicked flame his bowels brent,
And of his bowels made his bloudie feast:
Her bleeding brest, and riuen bowels gor'd,
And all his bowels in his body brast:
He broke, and did his bowels disentrayle;
Stryuing in vaine that nigh his bowels brast,
How oft do they, their siluer bowers leaue,
And euery one with meekenesse to her bowes.
That the weake bowes, with so rich load opprest,
Of broken bowes and arrowes shiuered short,
And broke their bowes, and did their shooting marre,
Then bowing downe her aged backe, she kist
And to the Prince bowing with reuerence dew,
Who bowing low before her Maiestie,
A mighty Mazer bowle of wine was set,
And ouerthrew his bowle disdainfully;
And her faire lockes, which formerly were bownd
Through euery rowme he sought, and euery bowr,
And rising forth out of her baser bowre,
Feasting and courting both in bowre and hall;
In hast came rushing forth from inner bowre,
Nor voice was heard, nor wight was seene in bowre or hall.
The faultie soules from thence brought to his heauenly bowre.
And know it by the name; it hight the Bowre of blis.
She led him vp into a goodly bowre,
Who vsed in a darksome inner bowre
And idle pleasures in his[her] Bowre of Blisse,
That God hath built for his owne blessed bowre.
Doth ouerthrow the Bowre of blisse,
Whereas the Bowre of Blisse was situate;
When forth from virgin bowre she comes in th'early morne.
Now are they come nigh to the Bowre of blis
That earst was sought to decke both bed and bowre,
Into a bowre, disarmed for to bee,
Her fearfull feete towards the bowre she moued;
Yet she might all men vew out of her bowre?
But th'aged Nurse her calling to her bowre,
Most famous fruits of matrimoniall bowre,
To enter into that same balefull Bowre,
Banisht from Princely bowre to wastfull wood:
Deepe in the bottome of the sea, her bowre
To send thine Angell from her bowre of blis,
And left her blisfull bowre of ioy aboue,
Her natiue flesh, and staine her brothers bowre,
But Florimell with him vnto his bowre he bore.
His bowre is in the bottome of the maine,
But in close bowre her mewes from all mens sight,
They bene ybrought into a comely bowre,
The roring billowes beat his bowre so boystrously.
And left behind her in her secret bowre,
That forced them to seeke some couert bowre,
And dayly feasting both in bowre and hall,
To come forthwith vnto his Ladies bowre.
Being returned to his mothers bowre,
Then Britomart vnto a bowre was brought;
She forth yssew'd out of her loathed bowre,
Vnder the Idols feete in fearelesse bowre,
The warlike Amazon out of her bowre did peepe.
Thenceforth she streight into a bowre him brought,
Fit for Adicia, there to build her wicked bowre.
Where it in siluer bowre does hidden ly
Which though it on a lowly stalke doe bowre,
Vnto his bowre was brought, and there vndrest,
And this your cabin both my bowre and hall.
Spredding pauilions for the birds to bowre,
With bowres, and beds, and Ladies deare delight:
Full of faire windowes, and delightfull bowres;
Haue borne him hence to Plutoes balefull bowres.
Fell from high Princes courts, or Ladies bowres,
Iread you rest, and to your bowres recoyle.
The woods, the Nymphes, my bowres, my midwiues weare,
When euer they their heauenly bowres forlore;
But all those pleasant bowres and Pallace braue,
Vnto their bowres to guiden euery guest:
From her sweet bowres, and beds with pleasures fraught:
In beds, in bowres, in banckets, and in feasts:
Them go to rest. So all vnto their bowres were brought.
Their girlonds rent, their bowres despoyled all;
Delightfull bowres, to solace louers trew;
The spring breake forth out of his lusty bowres,
In which the fearefull ewftes do build their bowres,
His rawbone armes, whose mighty brawned bowrs
Prince Arthur gaue a boxe of Diamond sure,
And poore mens boxes of their due reliefe,
And to him playnd, how that false winged boy,
A gentle Hynd, the which the louely boy
And bore a boy vnto that saluage sire:
Go find some other play-fellowes, mine own sweet boy.
Whose prouder vaunt that proud auenging boy
The most vnruly, and the boldest boy,
A litle boy did on him still attend,
That boy them sought, and vnto him did lend.
Entyst the Boy, as well that art she knew,
Nought like (quoth she) for that same wretched boy
Where when they saw that goodly boy, with blood
But foolish boy, what bootes thy seruice bace
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
And reape sweet pleasure of the wanton boy;
Which thither haunt, and with the winged boy
On faire Oenone got a louely boy,
The fearefull boy so greedily pursew,
On which the winged boy in colours cleare
Againe, when as the Troiane boy so faire
The winged boy did thrust into his throne,
In which that boy thee plonged, for despight,
The first was Fancy, like a louely boy,
The woody Nimphs, and with that louely boy,
Like as it fell to this vnhappy boy,
Then turning backe vnto that gentle boy,
I haue not tasted yet, yet past a boy,
That he these words burst forth; Ah sory boy,
The hardy boy, as they deuised had,
Of the blynd boy, ne thence could be redeemed
Mingled emongst loose Ladies and lasciuious boyes.
With vermell, like the boyes bloud therein shed,
Was ouer-wrought, and shapes of naked boyes,
Many faire Ladies, and lasciuious boyes,
Confusd with womens cries, and shouts of boyes,
Whose shapes seem'd not like to terrestriall boyes,
And bursting forth in teares; Ah my sweet boyes,
The whiles the viandes in the vessell boyld
To feeding of her priuate fire, which boyld
And drinke of euery brooke, when thirst my throte doth boyle.
Doth burne the earth, and boyled riuers drie,
Through boyling sands of Arabie and Ynde;
Which shielded them against the boyling heat,
As burning Aetna from his boyling stew
And suncke so deepe into their boyling brests,
Behold the boyling Bathes at Cairbadon,
She bath'd her brest, the boyling heat t'allay;
The pleasant Boyne, the fishy fruitfull Ban,
Yet was admired much of fooles, women, and boys.
His boystrous club, so buried in the ground,
And boystrous battell make, each other to auenge.
And round about with boystrous strokes oppresse,
The roring billowes beat his bowre so boystrously.
Tho hurling high his yron braced arme,
Now Bracidas let this likewise be showne.
And so the threasure yours is Bracidas by right.
But Bracidas and Lucy were right glad,
And through the brackish waues their passage sheare;
Dropped with brackish deaw; his three-forkt Pyke
Vaine Braggadocchio getting Guyons
Trompart fit man for Braggadocchio,
When Braggadocchio said, Once I did sweare,
In which vaine Braggadocchio was mewed,
And I (said Braggadocchio) thought no lesse,
Which he had brought for Braggadocchio vaine.
Proud Braggadocchio, that in vaunting vaine
Proud man himselfe then Braggadocchio deemed,
Sith then (said Braggadocchio) needes thou wilt
But Braggadocchio with his bloudie lance
But it was scornefull Braggadocchio,
He that from Braggadocchio whilome reft
But boastfull Braggadocchio rather chose,
Which Braggadocchio seeing, had no will
She, that base Braggadochio did affray,
Which Ferrau late from Braggadochio wonne,
But Braggadochio said, he neuer thought
Stept Braggadochio forth, and as his thrall
At last to Braggadochio selfe alone
By Braggadochio lately was redeemed.
There Braggadochio is vncas'd
With Braggadochio, whom he lately met
To Braggadochio did his shield restore:
Came Braggadochio, and did shew his shield,
And Braggadochio selfe with dreriment
And boastfull Braggadochio to defame,
For Braggadochio would not let him pas;
Don Braggadochios name resounded thrise:
Yet knight was not for all his bragging bost,
As one then in a dreame, whose dryer braine
That troublous dreame gan freshly tosse his braine,
That rots the marrow, and consumes the braine:
Of some th'aboundance of an idle braine
Quite through his braine. He tombling downe on ground,
And thousand fancies bet his idle braine
And thousands like, which flowed in his braine,
It would haue cleft his braine downe to his brest.
His ydle braine gan busily molest,
That it empierced to the very braine,
Doe tosse, that it will stonne thy feeble braines,
At last his solemne silence thus he brake,
And twixt the perles and rubins softly brake
And girded with a belt of twisted brake,
Ne hedge ne ditch his readie passage brake,
Yet when his loue was false, he with a peaze it brake.
Octa and Oza, whom he lately brake
So much they did, that at the last they brake
It forth to wrest, the staffe a sunder brake,
On him, the which his quiet slomber brake:
When so he heard her say, eftsoones he brake
For old despight, which now forth newly brake
But thus brake forth, that all the temple it did fill.
And when as he him nam'd, for ioy he brake
They hew'd their helmes, and plates asunder brake,
That all his bones in peeces nigh he brake.
That with one fall his necke he almost brake,
Some like wild Bores late rouzd out of the brakes;
With thornes and barren brakes enuirond round,
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
That through long languour, and hart-burning brame
That in his hand a branch of laurell bore,
And deckes his branch with blossomes ouer all,
Well worthy stock, from which the branches sprong,
